question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: George can only give a report on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. In A, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, but Olivia is Tuesday afternoon, which violates Olivia’s rule. In B, George is Tuesday morning, and Olivia is Monday afternoon, which also violates Olivia’s rule. In C, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Wednesday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In D, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In E, George is Tuesday morning, and Nina is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, and neither Olivia nor Robert gives an afternoon report, so both of their rules are also satisfied. So only E could be the schedule.
full_output:
<think>George can only give a report on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. In A, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, but Olivia is Tuesday afternoon, which violates Olivia’s rule. In B, George is Tuesday morning, and Olivia is Monday afternoon, which also violates Olivia’s rule. In C, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Wednesday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In D, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In E, George is Tuesday morning, and Nina is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, and neither Olivia nor Robert gives an afternoon report, so both of their rules are also satisfied. So only E could be the schedule.</think>
<ans>E</ans>

At least three but no more than four novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has less than three novels. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has fewer French novels than Russian novels. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, so eliminate any option that has both French plays and the Russian play. Options A, C, and D fail the novel limit, E fails the novel limit and the French/Russian novel count, and B satisfies all conditions.
full_output:

At least three but no more than four novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has less than three novels. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has fewer French novels than Russian novels. question:

chain_of_thought: Test each option against the rules: T is before F or after R, at least two compositions are after F and before R, or after R and before F, O is first or fifth, the eighth is L or H, and P is before S. In option A, T is after R, so it fails the first rule. In option B, T is before F, so it satisfies the first rule. Each session will be led by a different lab assistant—Julio, Kevin, Lan, Nessa, Olivia, or Rebecca. The assignment of lab assistants to sessions is constrained as follows: Kevin and Rebecca must lead sessions that meet on the same day. Lan and Olivia cannot lead sessions that meet on the same day. Nessa must lead an afternoon session. Julio's session must meet on an earlier day of the week than Olivia's.

If Julio and Kevin both lead morning sessions, then any of the following could be true EXCEPT:
A) Lan's session meets Wednesday morning.
B) Lan's session meets Thursday afternoon.
C) Nessa's session meets Friday afternoon.
D) Olivia's session meets Thursday morning.
E) Olivia's session meets Friday morning.
chain_of_thought: Julio and Kevin are both morning sessions, so they must be on Wednesday or Thursday. Since Kevin and Rebecca must be on the same day, they must be on Wednesday or Thursday as well. Nessa is an afternoon session. If Kevin is on Wednesday, then Rebecca is on Wednesday and Nessa can be on Thursday afternoon or Friday afternoon. If Kevin is on Thursday, then Rebecca is on Thursday, and Nessa can be on Friday afternoon. Julio is earlier than Olivia, so Olivia must be on Thursday or Friday. Lan and Olivia cannot be on the same day, so Lan must be on Wednesday or Friday. If Julio is on Wednesday, then Olivia must be on Friday and Lan can be on Wednesday morning. If Julio is on Thursday, then Olivia can be on Friday and Lan can be on Wednesday morning or Friday morning. This means Lan can be on Wednesday morning, so B is not true. Nessa must be on Friday afternoon, so C is true. Olivia can be on Thursday morning or Friday morning, so D and E are true. Therefore, the statement that must be false is A: Lan's session meets Wednesday morning.
full_output:
<think>Julio and Kevin are both morning sessions, so they must be on Wednesday or Thursday. Since Kevin and Rebecca must be on the same day, they must be on Wednesday or Thursday as well. Nessa is an afternoon session. If Kevin is on Wednesday, then Rebecca is on Wednesday and Nessa can be on Thursday afternoon or Friday afternoon. If Kevin is on Thursday, then Rebecca is on Thursday, and Nessa can be on Friday afternoon. Julio is earlier than Olivia, so Olivia must be on Thursday or Friday. Lan and Olivia cannot be on the same day, so Lan must be on Wednesday or Friday. If Julio is on Wednesday, then Olivia must be on Friday and Lan can be on Wednesday morning. If Julio is on Thursday, then Olivia can be on Friday and Lan can be on Wednesday morning or Friday morning. This means Lan can be on Wednesday morning, so B is not true. Nessa must be on Friday afternoon, so C is true. Olivia can be on Thursday morning or Friday morning, so D and E are true. Therefore, the statement that must be false is A: Lan's session meets Wednesday morning.</think>
<ans>A</ans>

question:
A chemistry class has six lab sessions scheduled over three days—Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday—one session heing held each morning and one each afternoon. Each session will be led by a different lab assistant—Julio, Kevin, Lan, Nessa, Olivia, or Rebecca. The assignment of lab assistants to sessions is constrained as follows: Kevin and Rebecca must lead sessions that meet on the same day. Lan and Olivia cannot lead sessions that meet on the same day. Nessa must lead an afternoon session. Julio's session must meet on an earlier day of the week than Olivia's.

If Julio leads the Thursday afternoon session, then for how many of the other lab assistants can one determine which sessions they lead?
A) one
B) two
C) three
D) four
E) five
chain_of_thought: Since Kevin and Rebecca must lead sessions on the same day and Nessa leads an afternoon session, the possibilities for Thursday are Julio (afternoon), Kevin and Rebecca (morning), or Nessa (afternoon). If Julio leads Thursday afternoon, Nessa must lead Thursday afternoon, so Kevin and Rebecca must lead Thursday morning. The only remaining day for Lan and Olivia is Friday. The only remaining session for Julio is Wednesday, so Olivia must lead Wednesday morning. This leaves Julio and Kevin/Rebecca for the Friday sessions, but since Julio leads Wednesday, Kevin and Rebecca must lead Friday. This means we can determine the sessions for Olivia (Wednesday), Nessa (Thursday), Kevin (Thursday), and Rebecca (Thursday), for a total of four lab assistants.
full_output:
<think>Since Kevin and Rebecca must lead sessions on the same day and Nessa leads an afternoon session, the possibilities for Thursday are Julio (afternoon), Kevin and Rebecca (morning), or Nessa (afternoon). If Julio leads Thursday afternoon, Nessa must lead Thursday afternoon, so Kevin and Rebecca must lead Thursday morning. The only remaining day for Lan and Olivia is Friday. The only remaining session for Julio is Wednesday, so Olivia must lead Wednesday morning. This leaves Julio and Kevin/Rebecca for the Friday sessions, but since Julio leads Wednesday, Kevin and Rebecca must lead Friday. This means we can determine the sessions for Olivia (Wednesday), Nessa (Thursday), Kevin (Thursday), and Rebecca (Thursday), for a total of four lab assistants.</think>
<ans>D</ans>

question:
A shopping center has exactly seven spaces—space 1 through space 7—arranged in a straight row. Seven businesses—an optometrist, a pharmacy, two restaurants, a shoe store, a toy store, and a veterinarian—will be located in the shopping center, one in each space. The locations of the businesses are subject to the following constraints: The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one of the restaurants at the other. The two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses. The pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian.

Which one of the following could be the order of the businesses in spaces 1 through 7 respectively?
A) pharmacy, optometrist, shoe store, restaurant, veterinarian, toy store, restaurant
B) pharmacy, veterinarian, optometrist, shoe store, restaurant, toy store, restaurant
C) restaurant, shoe store, veterinarian, pharmacy, optometrist, toy store, restaurant
D) restaurant, toy store, optometrist, restaurant, veterinarian, shoe store, pharmacy
E) restaurant, optometrist, toy store, restaurant, shoe store, veterinarian, pharmacy
chain_of_thought: The pharmacy must be at one end, so we can start by placing it at either end. Let’s place it at the left end, space 1. Now, one of the restaurants must be at the other end, so we can place it at space 7. We also know that the pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian, so we can place the optometrist or the veterinarian at space 2. Since the two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses, we cannot place the second restaurant at space 3. This leaves us with the options of placing the second restaurant at space 4 or space 5. We can place the second restaurant at space 5, and then place the remaining businesses in the spaces in between. Since the toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian, we can place the toy store at space 6, and the remaining business, the shoe store, at space 3. This leaves us with the following order: pharmacy, optometrist, shoe store, restaurant, veterinarian, toy store, restaurant. Now, let’s check if this order satisfies all the conditions. The pharmacy is at one end, and one of the restaurants is at the other end. The two restaurants are separated by at least two other businesses. The pharmacy is next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The toy store is not next to the veterinarian. Therefore, the order satisfies all the conditions.
full_output:
<think>The pharmacy must be at one end, so we can start by placing it at either end. Let’s place it at the left end, space 1. Now, one of the restaurants must be at the other end, so we can place it at space 7. We also know that the pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian, so we can place the optometrist or the veterinarian at space 2. Since the two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses, we cannot place the second restaurant at space 3. This leaves us with the options of placing the second restaurant at space 4 or space 5. We can place the second restaurant at space 5, and then place the remaining businesses in the spaces in between. Since the toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian, we can place the toy store at space 6, and the remaining business, the shoe store, at space 3. This leaves us with the following order: pharmacy, optometrist, shoe store, restaurant, veterinarian, toy store, restaurant. Now, let’s check if this order satisfies all the conditions. The pharmacy is at one end, and one of the restaurants is at the other end. The two restaurants are separated by at least two other businesses. The pharmacy is next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The toy store is not next to the veterinarian. Therefore, the order satisfies all the conditions.</think>
<ans>A</ans>

question:
A shopping center has exactly seven spaces—space 1 through space 7—arranged in a straight row. Seven businesses—an optometrist, a pharmacy, two restaurants, a shoe store, a toy store, and a veterinarian—will be located in the shopping center, one in each space. The locations of the businesses are subject to the following constraints: The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one of the restaurants at the other. The two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses. The pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian.

If the shoe store is in space 4, which one of the following must be true?
A) The optometrist is next to a restaurant.
B) The pharmacy is next to the veterinarian.
C) A restaurant is next to the toy store.
D) The shoe store is next to the toy store.
E) The shoe store is next to the veterinarian.
chain_of_thought: The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one restaurant at the other, and the two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses. If the shoe store is in space 4, the two restaurants cannot be in spaces 1 and 7 because they would be separated by only one space. They also cannot be in spaces 2 and 6 because the pharmacy would be next to one restaurant but not the other, violating the condition that the pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The only valid positions for the two restaurants are spaces 1 and 5, or spaces 7 and 3. If the two restaurants are in spaces 1 and 5, the pharmacy must be in space 7 and the optometrist or veterinarian in space 6. If the two restaurants are in spaces 7 and 3, the pharmacy must be in space 1 and the optometrist or veterinarian in space 2. In both cases, the toy store cannot be in space 2 because the veterinarian would be in space 2 and the toy store would be next to the veterinarian. In both cases, the toy store cannot be in space 6 because the optometrist would be in space 6 and the toy store would be next to the optometrist. Therefore, the toy store must be in either space 5 or space 3, and in both cases, a restaurant would be next to the toy store.
full_output:
<think>The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one restaurant at the other, and the two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses. If the shoe store is in space 4, the two restaurants cannot be in spaces 1 and 7 because they would be separated by only one space. They also cannot be in spaces 2 and 6 because the pharmacy would be next to one restaurant but not the other, violating the condition that the pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The only valid positions for the two restaurants are spaces 1 and 5, or spaces 7 and 3. If the two restaurants are in spaces 1 and 5, the pharmacy must be in space 7 and the optometrist or veterinarian in space 6. If the two restaurants are in spaces 7 and 3, the pharmacy must be in space 1 and the optometrist or veterinarian in space 2. In both cases, the toy store cannot be in space 2 because the veterinarian would be in space 2 and the toy store would be next to the veterinarian. In both cases, the toy store cannot be in space 6 because the optometrist would be in space 6 and the toy store would be next to the optometrist. Therefore, the toy store must be in either space 5 or space 3, and in both cases, a restaurant would be next to the toy store.</think>
<ans>C</ans>

A) Zone 1: Kim, Parra Zone 2: Stuckey, Udall Zone 3: Mahr, Quinn, Tiao
B) Zone 1: Kim, Tiao Zone 2: Stuckey, Udall Zone 3: Mahr, Parra, Quinn
C) Zone 1: Parra, Quinn Zone 2: Kim, Udall Zone 3: Mahr, Stuckey, Tiao
D) Zone 1: Stuckey, Udall Zone 2: Kim, Tiao Zone 3: Mahr, Parra, Quinn
E) Zone 1: Tiao Zone 2: Kim, Parra, Quinn Zone 3: Stuckey, Udall
chain_of_thought: Either Parra or Tiao works in Zone 1, and Parra and Quinn work in the same zone. So Parra and Quinn must be in Zone 1 or 3, but not 2. Also, either Tiao or Udall works in Zone 2, so Tiao and Udall must be in Zone 1 or 2, but not 3. Stuckey and Udall work in the same zone as each other, so they must be in Zone 2 or 3, but not 1. Also, there are more people in Zone 3 than in Zone 2. Since Parra and Quinn must be in Zone 1 or 3, and there are more people in Zone 3 than in Zone 2, then Parra and Quinn must be in Zone 3. This leaves Zone 1 for Stuckey and Udall. So, either Tiao or Udall is in Zone 2. If Tiao is in Zone 2, then Udall is in Zone 1, and Kim is in Zone 3. If Udall is in Zone 2, then Tiao is in Zone 1, and Kim is in Zone 3. The only option that satisfies these conditions is C.

So the second solo must be modern. The only remaining possibility is that the fifth solo is traditional. If the first solo is traditional, then there are no two consecutive traditional pieces. So the first solo must be modern. This leaves the possibility that the second, third, and fifth solos are traditional, with the fourth solo being modern.

A) Image's voicemail target is 2 days.
B) Image's website target is 2 days.
C) Image's website target is 1 day.
D) Solide's website target is 2 days.
E) Solide's website target is 1 day.
chain_of_thought: Truvest's website target must be shorter than its voicemail target. This is a contradiction to the rule that none of the clients can have a website target that is longer than its voicemail target. The only way to resolve this is to eliminate the possibility of this situation occurring. This means that Truvest's website target and voicemail target must be equal, as it cannot be longer. This makes it impossible for Image's voicemail target to be shorter than the other clients' voicemail targets (since Truvest's voicemail target would be equal to the others), so Image's voicemail target must be the same as the others. Since Image's voicemail target must be shorter than the other clients' voicemail targets, Image's voicemail target must be 1 day. Therefore, Image's website target must also be 1 day, because it cannot be longer than the voicemail target. This means that option C must be true.
full_output:
<think>Truvest's website target must be shorter than its voicemail target. This is a contradiction to the rule that none of the clients can have a website target that is longer than its voicemail target. The only way to resolve this is to eliminate the possibility of this situation occurring. This means that Truvest's website target and voicemail target must be equal, as it cannot be longer. This makes it impossible for Image's voicemail target to be shorter than the other clients' voicemail targets (since Truvest's voicemail target would be equal to the others), so Image's voicemail target must be the same as the others. Since Image's voicemail target must be shorter than the other clients' voicemail targets, Image's voicemail target must be 1 day. Therefore, Image's website target must also be 1 day, because it cannot be longer than the voicemail target. This means that option C must be true.</think>
<ans>C</ans>
